name: Peter Forbes
comment info:
What do you notice?
I notice that from 1901 to 1930, the relative precipitation is pretty evenly spread across the US. From 1931 to 1960, the relative precipitation is very low, with the most dry areas being around the Midwest and the Southwest. From 1961 to 1990, the relative precipitation is also pretty evenly spread, with maybe a bit more precipitation overall. From 1991 to 2020, the relative precipitation is very high, with most of it concentrated in the Northeast and the Midwest.

What do you wonder?
I wonder why the precipitation levels fluctuate so much across the US?

How does this relate to you and your community?
Ever since I was born, I've noticed that it very rarely rains in Arizona, and I always wondered if Arizona was always like this. This data shows that Arizona wasn't always like this. Across the four time spans given in the graph, Arizona changes from having above average precipitation between 1901 and 1930, to having below average precipitation between 1931 and 1960, to having above average precipitation between 1961 and 1990, to having below average precipitation.

name: Maria
comment info:
I notice from this data that the levels of precipitation have dramatically increased on the Eastern side of the country, making it have a more wet climate, while the Southwest, in contrast, has become more of a dry environment throughout the years. Thus, from 1901-60, most of the West and East seemed to have a drier climate than from 1961-2020, which shows the transition into the wet environment in the majority of the East.
I wonder whether global warming is a factor in this change in the climate. The warmer the air is, the higher the humidity and quicker evaporation of water which prompts tropical storms and hurricanes that have been occurring more lately. Another factor that may play into this is geography. For example, a state such as Arizona, with its canyons and deserts, already contains a dry climate, and global warming elevates that climate.

name: Sharon HESSNEY
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's line moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graphs, which are displayed as maps called choropleths, show the percentage change in average U.S. precipitation for three 30-year periods .  The data for these graphs are collected from over 15,000 weather stations around the country, including more than 8,000 stations operated by volunteers.  Volunteers have gathered data since 1890.  This is one of the oldest and largest citizen-science projects anywhere.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “How does this relate to you and your community?”  Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in this graph. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the free link to the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

View our archives with free link: organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, Sept. 24 with moderation on Wednesday, Sept. 29.  The topic:  2020 Census and state redistricting.  Keep noticing and wondering!

After viewing this graph, I noticed that the precipitation levels have gradually risen over the last 100 years. The graph says that precipitation levels have risen over 9% in the majority of the U.S. While I don’t know the exact reason for this gradual increase, I can infer that it is due to climate change and the melting of glaciers. The melting of glaciers causes an abundance of fresh water to be available for evaporation. 
        This is very concerning because if there is more water available and more precipitation, this can cause sea levels to rise therefore putting our future generations in danger. While I don't believe we can stop climate change and global warming, I think we can limit its impact on our earth. Our country can start by investing in renewable energy sources such as windmills, solar farms, and hydroelectricity. These are great methods for maintaining a steady climate.

name: Lucas Garcia
comment info:
What do you notice?

I noticed that the precipitation averaged in some of the U.S. in 1901-1930, then a little bit less than that in 1931-1960, then significantly more precipitation in 1961-1990, and then a lot more precipitation in 1991-2020. I also noticed that there was always a large part of California that was relatively dry compared to other states in all four of the 30-year periods. 

What do you wonder?

I wondered why the precipitation average has been increasing. Another thing that I wondered was why the east coast and the north seem to get more precipitation than the rest of the country. 

How does this relate to you and your community?

This relates to me and my community because my community seems to suffer from a relatively high precipitation average and has been for more decades.
